node.name: Category
node.description: This is meant to designate the reason this event was recorded.

node.name: Initial context
node.description: The purpose is to set the starting context for the experiment --- and if there is no initial context event---this information would be stored as a dataset tag.

node.name: Participant response
node.description: The purpose of this event was to record the state or response of a participant. note: participant actions may occur in other kinds of events, such as the experimenter records a terrain change as an event and the participant happens to be walking. in this case the event category would be ‘environmental’. in contrast, if the participant started walking in response to an instruction or to some other stimulus, the event would be recorded as ‘participant response’.

node.name: Technical error
node.description: Experimenters forgot to turn on something, the cord snagged, etc. and something may be wrong with the data.
Description as string.

node.name: Participant failure
node.description: Situation in which participant acts outside of the constraints of the experiment -- such as driving outside the boundary of a simulation experiment or using equipment incorrectly.
Description as string.

node.name: Environmental
node.description: Change in experimental context, e.g walking on dirt versus sidewalk.
Description as a string.

node.name: Experimental procedure
node.description: Like doing a saliva swab on the person.

node.name: Incidental
node.description: Not a part of the task as perceived by/instructed to the participant, e.g. an airplane flew by and made noise, a random person showed up on the street.

node.name: Miscellaneous
node.description: Events that are only have informational value and cannot be put in other event categories.

node.name: Experiment control
node.description: Information about states and events of the software program that controls the experiment.
Permutation number/code used for permuted experiment parts.

node.name: Experiment
node.description: Use onset and offset to indicate start and end of the experiment.

node.name: Block
node.description: Each block has the same general context and contains several trials, use attribute/onset and attribute/offset to specify start and end.
Block number.
Trial number.

node.name: Pause
node.description: Use attribute/onset and attribute/offset to specify start and end.
Label here.

node.name: Activity
node.description: Experiment-specific actions, such as moving a piece in a chess game.

node.name: Participant action
node.description: E.g moving a chess piece.

node.name: Missed
node.description: They failed to have, or could not have, perceived the question due to their eyes being off-screen or a similar reason. not easy to deduce this but it is possible.

node.name: Incorrect
node.description: Wrong choice but not time out.

node.name: Inappropriate
node.description: A choice that is not allowed or not being presented was selected, e.g. selected c while the choices where a and b, or moved the chess piece to a location it should not go based on game rules.
Actual tag: string or integer.
Experiment parameters in some a string. do not used quotes, like "" or ''.

node.name: Sequence group ID
node.description: A number or string label that uniquely identifies a group of events associated with each[kr2] other, e.g. answer to a question, possibly interleaved by other events..
Id of the group.

node.name: Duration
node.description: An offset is implicit after duration time passed from the onset.

node.name: Description
node.description: Same as hed 1.0 description for human-readable text.

node.name: Label
node.description: A short, e.g. less than 20 characters, label for the event. for example /label/accept button. please note that the information under this tag is primarily not for use in the analysis and is provided for the convenience in referring to events in the context of a single study. please use custom tag to define custom event hierarchies. please do not mention onset and offset in the label. these should only be placed in attribute/onset.. and then a software automatically generates a final label with (onset) or (offset) in parentheses added to the original label. this will make it easier to automatically find onset and offsets for the same event. .
Ns3.

node.name: ID
node.description: Optional.

node.name: Local
node.description: For ids with local scope i.e. only defined in the scope of a single event e.g. local id 5 in events 1 and 2 may refer to two different objects, while global ids, directly under id/ tag refer to the same object through the whole experiment.

node.name: Group ID
node.description: Optional.

node.name: Object
node.description: Ns6][visually discernable, excludes sounds, which are items but not objects.

node.name: NA
node.description: Extend here.

node.name: 3D shape
node.description: Ns7.

node.name: NA
node.description: Extend here.

node.name: 2D shape
node.description: Ns8][geometric shapes.

node.name: Cross
node.description: By default a vertical-horizontal cross, for rotated add /rotated/ tag.

node.name: Clock face
node.description: Used to study things like hemispheric neglect, related to ‘clock drawing test’.
Hour:min.

node.name: NA
node.description: Extend here.

node.name: Pattern
node.description: Ns9.

node.name: NA
node.description: Extend here.

node.name: Symbolic
node.description: Something that has a meaning, could be linguistic or not, a writing, stop signs, etc...

node.name: Sign
node.description: Like the icon on a stop sign, not to be confused with the actual object e.g. a stop sign itself.
Always give units e.g. mph or kph.

node.name: Pseudo-character
node.description: Alphabet-like but not really.

node.name: Letter
node.description: Authograph, valid letters including numbers, e.g. a, b, 5...,.

node.name: Composite
node.description: Has multiple of the above on it, may need reconsideration] [kr10][ns11.

node.name: Drawing
node.description: E.g. cartoons.

node.name: IAPS
node.description: International affective picture system.

node.name: IADS
node.description: International affective digital sounds.

node.name: SAM
node.description: The self-assessment manikin.

node.name: Sensory presentation
node.description: Object manifestation.

node.name: Auditory
node.description: Sound.

node.name: Ding
node.description: Often positive valence.

node.name: Buzz
node.description: Often negative valence.

node.name: ABR
node.description: Auditory brainstem response.

node.name: Colored
node.description: Not white, 1/f, spectrum.

node.name: Real world
node.description: People walking, machines, etc...

node.name: Nonvocal
node.description: A car engine, gears grinding, everything that is not made by a human or an animal.

node.name: Olfactory
node.description: Odor.

node.name: Tactile
node.description: Pressure.

node.name: View port
node.description: E.g. two views on the same object, one from top one from street view.
Label of the viewport, e.g. "birds-eye view".

node.name: Motion-capture
node.description: E.g. stick figure of motion capture of someone else.
In hz.

node.name: LED
node.description: Stimulus is turning on/off a one or a few leds.

node.name: Object side
node.description: Could be a person’s left and right sides, or a car’s passenger side.

node.name: Reference object ID
node.description: Place object id after this.

node.name: Passenger side
node.description: Side of a car.

node.name: Driver side
node.description: Side of a car.

node.name: Bow
node.description: Front of a ship.

node.name: Stern
node.description: Back of the ship.

node.name: Onset
node.description: Default.

node.name: Peak
node.description: E.g. for peak velocity, acceleration or jerk.

node.name: State ID
node.description: This is used to identify a group of events that are changing the state of a variable, the onset of each means the offset of any other and a change in the state.
Id, could be a number or any string.

node.name: Social
node.description: Involving interactions among multiple agents, e.g. humans, dogs, robots...

node.name: Repetition
node.description: When the same events, e.g. fixation on the exact same object, happens multiple times it might be necessary to distinguish first look vs. others.
Number, starting from 1= first time it occurs, 2 = second time,....

node.name: Direction
node.description: Coordinate system is inferred from /location, to specify a vector combine subnodes with number, e.g. direction/top/10, direction/left/5 to create a (10,5) vector.

node.name: Top
node.description: You can combine top+left to get upperleft and so on.

node.name: Angle
node.description: Clockwise angle in degrees, from vertical.
Clockwise angle in degrees, from vertical.

node.name: Forward
node.description: Like a car moving forward.

node.name: Backward
node.description: Like a car moving backward.

node.name: Location
node.description: Spot, center of an area, use area were you are referring to something with significant extent and emphasizing its boundaries, like a city.
Location label.

node.name: Screen
node.description: Specify displacements from each subnode in pixels, degrees or meters. specify a unit, e.g. location/screen/top/12 px.

node.name: Top
node.description: You can combine top and left to designate upperleft and so on.
Clockwise angle in degrees, from vertical.
Displacement from screen center, in any direction, in degrees, cm, or other lengths.
Displacement from screen center, in any direction.
Displacement from screen center, in any direction.

node.name: Lane
node.description: E.g. car lane.

node.name: Passing
node.description: The lane that cars use to take over other cars.

node.name: xyz
node.description: Have a subnode, e.g. /room/xyz/[10 50 30.
Distance, by[kr12] default in meters.
Preferably in degrees, clockwise.
Preferably in degrees.
In degrees, e.g 5 degrees.
In meters, e.g. 5 meters.
In degrees, e.g 5 degrees.

node.name: Item count
node.description: Number of items, e.g. 3 when there are 3 cars and they are identified as a single item.
Number of item equal to #.
Number of item less than or equal to #.
Number of item more than or equal to #.
In hz.
In db.

node.name: Ramp up
node.description: Increasing in amplitude.

node.name: Ramp down
node.description: Decreasing in amplitude.

node.name: Up-down Separated
node.description: Stimuli presented both at the top and the bottom of fovea.
Separation in degrees.

node.name: Bilateral
node.description: For bilateral visual field stimulus presentations.
Separation in degrees.
E.g. /3 degrees.
E.g. /3 degrees.
E.g. /3 degrees.
E.g. /3 degrees.
In candela, e.g 25 cd.

node.name: Aqua
node.description: These are css 3 basic color names, available in appendix 1.
R value of rgb, between 0 and 1.
B value of rgb, between 0 and 1.
G value of rgb, between 0 and 1.
H value of hsv, between 0 and 1.
S value of hsv, between 0 and 1.
V value of hsv, between 0 and 1.

node.name: Achromatic
node.description: Gray, is only in black, white or between.
White intensity between 0 and 1.

node.name: Nonlinguistic
node.description: E.g. iconic pictures of a man or a woman on the doors of restrooms, or deer crossing sign which just has a picture of jumping deer..

node.name: Semantic
node.description: Like in priming or in congruence.

node.name: Proper
node.description: A proper noun, refers to a unique entity, such as london, jupiter, ....
Number of words.
Number of sentences.
Number of paragraphs.

node.name: Story
node.description: Multiple paragraphs making a detailed account.

node.name: Induced
node.description: Like inducing emotions, or keeping someone awake or in a coma with an external intervention.

node.name: Arousal
node.description: Only in the context of 2d emotion representation.
Between -1 and 1.

node.name: Positive valence
node.description: Since valence by itself can be the name of an emotion, e.g. sadness is a type of valence, we place here two, positive valence and negative valence to make the language more clear.
From 0 to 1.
From 0 to 1.

node.name: Supraliminal
node.description: By default this is what assumed about each stimulus.

node.name: Liminal
node.description: At the 75%/25% perception threshold.

node.name: Probability
node.description: E.g. for oddball.

node.name: Velocity
node.description: Use attribute/onset, offset or peak to specify onset, peak… velocity, jerk, etc.
Numeric value in m/s.
Numeric value in m/s2.
Numeric value in m/s3.

node.name: Constrained
node.description: E.g. path cannot cross some region.

node.name: File
node.description: File name, size and other attributes.
Number and unit, e..g 2 kb, 5 mb, 1 gb.
Number of files.

node.name: Object control
node.description: Such as vehicle control.

node.name: Near miss
node.description: Almost having an accident resulting in negative consequences.

node.name: Correct position
node.description: E.g. after a lane deviation or side of the walkway.

node.name: Halt
node.description: The time when speed becomes exactly zero speed = 0.

node.name: Cross
node.description: Like crossing in front of another object, e.g., a vehicle.

node.name: Pass by
node.description: Passing by another object or the participant.

node.name: Another person
node.description: E.g. action of another person, cup belonging to of another person.

node.name: Same Person
node.description: E.g. cup belonging to the participant.

node.name: Action
node.description: May or may not be associated with a prior stimulus, can be extended.

node.name: Involuntary
node.description: Like sneezing, tripping on something, hiccuping….

node.name: Stumble
node.description: Temporary and involuntary loss of balance.

node.name: Tether Jerk
node.description: When a tether attached to the subject is stuck/snagged and forces the participant to involuntary accommodate/react to it.

node.name: Button hold
node.description: Press and keep pressed.

node.name: Cross boundary
node.description: Ns16.

node.name: Arrive
node.description: Ns17.

node.name: Depart
node.description: Ns18.

node.name: Eye saccade
node.description: Use attribute/peak for the middle of saccade, also onset and offset for its start and end.

node.name: Eye close
node.description: And keep closed for > ~0.1 s.

node.name: Eye open
node.description: And keep open for > ~0.1 s.

node.name: Turn
node.description: Change in direction of movement. this includes both turn during movement on a path and also rotations, e.g. head turns.

node.name: Tap
node.description: When there is nothing to be pressed, like tapping a finger on a chair surface to follow a rhythm.

node.name: Reach
node.description: Requires a goal, e.g. reach to touch a button or grab something. stretching your body does not count as reach.

node.name: Course correction
node.description: E.g. change the direction of a reach in the middle to adjust for a moving target.

node.name: Stretch
node.description: Body, e.g. when you wake up.

node.name: Intramodal
node.description: In the same modality, but for example pay attention to read dots and not blue dots.

node.name: Intermodal
node.description: Between modalities.

node.name: Control vehicle
node.description: Controlling an object that you are aboard.

node.name: Drive
node.description: Driving a vehicle, e.g. car.

node.name: Correct
node.description: E.g. correct for a perturbation.

node.name: Stop
node.description: E..g brake a car.

node.name: Pilot
node.description: E.g. an airplane.

node.name: Teleoperate
node.description: Controlling an object that you are not aboard.

node.name: Allow
node.description: E.g allow access to something, like allow to pass.

node.name: Deny
node.description: E.g. deny access to something, like prevent someone to pass.

node.name: ID
node.description: If not given assume 1.
Id number.

node.name: Role
node.description: Ns19] [the role of the participant associated with the event, e.g. viewer, follower, leader, is placed at a lower level, e.g. participant/role/leader.

node.name: Effect
node.description: Stimulus effects the participants, e.g. perceived by her.
Monetary values in some currency, for example $1, or the ratio of the reward to the maximum possible (3 of max 10 becomes 0.3), or x points.
Absolute monetary values in some currency, for example $1, or the ratio of the reward to the maximum possible (3 of max 10 becomes 0.3), or x points.

node.name: Planned
node.description: The error feedback was given regardless of the validity of subject response, e.g in a yoked design.

node.name: Warning
node.description: E.g. ‘warning: you are getting too close to the shoulder’ in a driving task.

node.name: Oddball
node.description: Unexpected or infrequent.

node.name: One stimulus
node.description: See http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0167-8760(96)00030-x, only oddballs present but no frequenct estimuli exist.

node.name: Two stimuli
node.description: See http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0167-8760(96)00030-x, in a two stimuli, there are non-targets and, targets.

node.name: Target
node.description: In a three stimuli, there are regular non-targets, targets and infrequent non-targets.

node.name: Target
node.description: Something the subject is looking for.

node.name: Novel
node.description: Genuine once or so per experiment event.

node.name: Expected
node.description: Of low information value.

node.name: Valid
node.description: Something is understood to be valid, e.g. an id matches the person showing it and has all the correct information.

node.name: Invalid
node.description: Something is understood to not be valid, like an id with impossible date-of-birth, or not matching the person showing it.

node.name: Congruent
node.description: Like in stroop paradigm, a blue text reading ‘blue’.

node.name: Incongruent
node.description: Like in stroop paradigm, a blue text reading ‘red’.

node.name: Synchronous
node.description: E.g. when a mouse click sound happens right after clicking it.

node.name: Asynchronous
node.description: E.g. when a mouse click sound happens with significant delay which give could the person a strange feeling. or if in a movie the sound of the explosion is heard before it happens.

node.name: Correct
node.description: Confirm, something went well, last action was correct.

node.name: Expected
node.description: Feedback was expected, for example they were often correct and they are again correct.

node.name: Unexpected
node.description: Feedback was expected, for example they were often correct and they are again correct.

node.name: On accuracy
node.description: Feedback was provided by evaluating their accuracy.

node.name: On reaction time
node.description: Feedback was provided by evaluating their reaction time.

node.name: To self
node.description: Default.

node.name: To other
node.description: Observed feedback to another person, typically in a social paradigm.

node.name: Deterministic
node.description: Should have a fixed relationship to what happened before.

node.name: Stochastic
node.description: Non-deterministic, it does not have fixed relationship with what has happened before in the experiment.

node.name: False feedback
node.description: Feedback that was not honest, e.g. feedback of correct on an incorrect response or vice versa.

node.name: Negative
node.description: Negative feedback was provided when it was not deserved.

node.name: Positive
node.description: Positive feedback was provided when it was not deserved.

node.name: Perturbation
node.description: E.g. sudden movement/perturbation of the virtual environment in a car driving scenario.

node.name: With SPGS
node.description: Spgs = spatial position guiding system.

node.name: Without SPGS
node.description: Spgs = spatial position guiding system.

node.name: Swab
node.description: E.g. mouth swab.

node.name: Small
node.description: Pinkie, little finger.

node.name: Neutral
node.description: None of the above.

node.name: Sense of community
node.description: Primed to have e.g. patriotism.
Sci = sense of community index.
A number between 0 and 1.
A number between 0 and 1.
Response window in seconds. not mandatory.

node.name: Competitive
node.description: Subject is competing against an opponent, for example when the faster respondent wins.

node.name: Social interaction
node.description: Social.

node.name: Pseudo
node.description: Instructed so but actually not, the other person may not exist in real world, e.g. be a computer program agent.

node.name: Passive
node.description: There is a stimulus presentation but no behavioral measurements are collected (asked from the subject). the instruction is “do not make any behavioral outputs”, for example carefully watch/listen/sense. resting state is not considered passive.

node.name: Resting
node.description: Resting state, no stimulus presentation and no behavioral outputs.

node.name: Top-down
node.description: Instructed to pay attention to something explicitly.

node.name: Bottom-up
node.description: Automatic, something captures your attention, like a big bang or your name.

node.name: Orienting
node.description: The lower state of the bottom-up, pre-bottom up state.

node.name: Covert
node.description: Implicit.

node.name: Overt
node.description: Explicit.

node.name: Selective
node.description: If you have two circles but asked to pay attention to only one of them.

node.name: Divided
node.description: Attending to more than one objects/locations....

node.name: Focused
node.description: Paying a lot of attention.

node.name: Sustained
node.description: Paying attention for a continuous time.

node.name: To a Location
node.description: Spatial, add the location attribute to specify to where.

node.name: Alerting
node.description: Keeping the arousal up in order to respond quickly.

node.name: Custom
node.description: This node can be used to organize events in an alternative (parallel) hierarchy: you can define your custom tags and hierarchies without any restriction under this node. these tags will still be matched to each other, for example /custom/dance/waltz is considered a subtype of /custom/dance. example: /initial score/# [monetary values in some currency, for example $1, or the ratio of the reward to the maximum possible (3 of max 10 becomes 0.3), or x points.

node.name: Experiment context
node.description: describes the context of the whole experiment or large portions of it, also includes tags that are common across all events, in the whole or large portions.
Add common tags across all stimuli/ and/or responses here, e.g if all experimental events share /state/drowsy, you can place it here instead of tagging each event individually ][kr21.

node.name: Prone
node.description: E.g. on a bed.
Speed meters per second.
Speed meters per second.

node.name: Indoors
node.description: Default.

node.name: Clinic
node.description: Recording in a clinical setting, e.g. in a hospital or doctor’s office.

node.name: Motion platform
node.description: Subject is on a motion platform, e.g. simulated car movements.

node.name: Distance
node.description: Assuming static subject.
Distance in meters from subject eyes to the presentation screen , e.g. 0.3 for 30 cm from subject eyes to the monitor.
In pixels.
In pixels.
In meters.
In meters.

node.name: NA
node.description: Extend here][ns22.

node.name: HED
node.description: Hierarchical event descriptor.

Hed specification version number: normally there is no need to specify the version number in the hed string since it will be matched by default to the most recent compliant version, but this tag can be used to specify the exact hed version the hed string was based on..

node.name: Behavioral rating inventory of executive function
Choice task between risky and non-risky options
Fagerstrom test for nicotine dependence (Cognitive Atlas Term)
Mini mental state examination (Cognitive Atlas Term)
Modified erikson scale of communication attitudes
Non-choice task to study expected value and uncertainty
NA
node.description: Extend here.

unitClass.name: physicalLength
unitClass.units: m, cm, km, mm, feet, foot, meter, meters, mile, miles

unitClass.name: time
unitClass.units: s, second, seconds, hour:min, day, days, ms, milliseconds, minute, minutes, hour, hours
